topic: Deno Deploy Hits GA and Launches Sandbox for AI-Generated Code
title: Deno Deploy Goes GA and Bets Big on Sandboxing AI-Generated Code
subtitle: General availability, Firecracker-powered microVMs for untrusted code, and a runtime that keeps pulling ahead on security
summary: Deno Deploy reached general availability on February 3, 2026, alongside the beta launch of Deno Sandbox, a Firecracker-powered microVM environment designed to safely execute AI-generated code. Combined with Deno 2.6's supply chain security features and the runtime's growing adoption by Netlify and Supabase, these releases mark Deno's clearest pitch yet as a full platform rather than just a Node.js alternative.

narrative_arc.hook: Deno Deploy hits general availability with a new sandboxing product aimed at the AI code execution problem nobody else has solved cleanly
narrative_arc.tension: Developers have been burned by runtime lock-in before, and Deno still holds just 3.5% market share against Node's dominance
narrative_arc.resolution: The technical decisions behind Deploy GA and Sandbox solve real security and deployment pain points that competitors haven't addressed
narrative_arc.transformation: From experimental alternative to credible production platform with a clear AI infrastructure play

sections.title: What Deno Just Shipped
sections.scaffold: Open with the Deploy GA and Sandbox announcements from February 3. Lead with the most newsworthy element: Deno Sandbox uses Firecracker microVMs to safely run AI-generated code. Then cover Deploy GA and what changed from the beta. Reference Deno 2.6 features that shipped in December. Frame why these releases together represent a platform play.
research_questions: What are the key features of Deno Sandbox?

sections.title: One Command to the Edge
sections.scaffold: Dig into Deno Deploy's GA release. Explain the V8 isolate architecture across 32 regions. Cover the new dashboard, framework auto-detection, and Node.js module support. Mention pricing and the free tier. Cite Netlify and Supabase as companies building on Deno's infrastructure.
research_questions: What is the technical architecture behind Deno Deploy?
Which companies use Deno Deploy infrastructure?
What does Deploy pricing look like?

sections.title: The AI Code Problem Nobody Solved Cleanly
sections.scaffold: Cover Deno Sandbox in depth. Explain the Firecracker microVM architecture, the defense-in-depth security model, and the JavaScript/Python SDKs. Discuss why AI code execution is a growing problem and how Deno's permission model gives it a structural advantage. Reference Anthropic's acquisition of Bun as context for how runtimes are positioning around AI.
research_questions: How does Deno Sandbox work technically?
What security guarantees does it provide?
How are other runtimes positioning around AI?

sections.title: Where This Leaves the Runtime Wars
sections.scaffold: Zoom out to the competitive landscape. Node.js 24 is the LTS standard. Bun is now Anthropic-owned. Deno is betting on platform over pure runtime. Mention remaining gaps: npm compatibility edge cases, enterprise adoption, JSR traction. Close with what to watch.
research_questions: What is the current market share of Deno vs Node.js vs Bun?
What are the known npm compatibility gaps in Deno?

metadata.target_audience: JavaScript and TypeScript developers, DevOps engineers, tech leads evaluating runtime choices
